stem: A client with depression was recently switched from phenelzine (an MAOI) to sertraline (an SSRI). Based on the documentation in the Psychopharmacology & Neuromuscular Log, what is the most likely cause of the client's current symptoms?

options.text: Serotonin syndrome due to inadequate washout period
Standard start-up side effects of sertraline

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing **serotonin syndrome (a1)**. This occurred because the 14-day 'washout' period for the MAOI (phenelzine) was not followed (only 3 days passed). The typical cues include **hyperreflexia**, **myoclonus** (jerking), **agitation**, **hyperactive bowel sounds**, and **mydriasis** (dilated pupils). While NMS (a2) also presents with high fever and agitation, NMS is characterized by 'lead-pipe rigidity' (stiffness) and *hypoactive* bowel sounds. Serotonin syndrome is 'hyper-everything' (twitchy/fast).
clinicalPearls: Serotonin syndrome = Shivering, Hyperreflexia, Increased Temperature, Encephalopathy, Restlessness, Sweating (SHIVERS).
Always wait 14 days when switching between MAOIs and SSRIs.
Treatment: Stop the medications, provide supportive care (cooling, fluids), and administer benzodiazepines for agitation/twitches.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing NMS (a2) because the fever is high (103.4°F).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Check the **muscle tone** and **reflexes**. Rigidity (stiff) = NMS. Myoclonus (jerky/twitchy) + hyperreflexia (fast) = serotonin syndrome.

exhibits.title: Medication Timeline
exhibits.content:
March 1: Discontinued phenelzine (Nardil).
March 4: Started sertraline (Zoloft) 50 mg daily.
Note: MAOIs require a 14-day 'washout' period before starting an SSRI to prevent drug interactions.

exhibits.title: Vital Signs & Neuro
exhibits.content:
Vitals: Temperature 103.4°F (39.7°C), BP 178/104 mm Hg, HR 134 bpm.
Assessment: Myoclonus (muscle jerking) noted in lower extremities. Hyperreflexia (4+) and tremor present. Diaphoresis. Dilated pupils (mydriasis).

exhibits.title: Nursing Observations
exhibits.content: Current: Client is highly agitated and confused. Hyperactive bowel sounds and diarrhea reported. No muscle rigidity (muscle is 'twitchy' rather than 'stiff').
